physDesc.p: This letter is two pages long. On the first page, “Poetry (Monroe)” is written in pencil at the top. The second page has, typed, H.M. with the corresponding page number in the top left corner, and the date (2/3/16) in the top right corner. On both pages, there is faint text on the page at the top. The text is large and mirrored on the opposite side of the page, It reads, “BERKSHIRE LINEN”

div.p: I feel that I owe you an apology for suspecting you of deleting Mrs. Freer's article of complimentary remarks about me. Naturally, after Mrs. Freer's perfectly clear message, I supposed that you had left out a great deal that was important. As a matter of fact, on reading through her manuscript, which came this morning, I find that you only left out things which could in no way add to the value of the review, and which, had I been editing the manuscript, I should have left out myself. Mrs. Freer is evidently unused to criticism, as her review is merely a recapitulation of what could be found in the book; but since she wrote it that way, I do not see what else you could do. I was very grateful to you for putting it in so promptly, and I am returning it at once. I trust that you will understand that, had it not been for Mrs. Freer's sending me so clear and strong a message, I should never have suspected you of leaving anything important out of the review. I imagine that what happened was that Mrs. Freer did not care very much for her own review when she saw it in print, and probably did not quite remember what the original was, but imagined it would have been better than what was printed. I am very glad you send it to me.

I also want to thank you very much for saying that you will change my list of poems in the Anthology
to suit me. I really cannot tell you how glad I glad I shall be if you change your mind in regard to "polyphonic prose" and allow "Lead Soldiers" to appear in the Anthology. It would a very great kindness to me if you could see your way to doing this.
You do not mention "Off the Turnpike," but I trust that, as silence gives consent, it means that you are going to accept it.
